ovdesc.p: This table allows the user to define for each currency and market, FORWARD exchange rates for any time period defined by the user. These periods can be defined either in months, e.g. 1 month, 2 months, 3 months, 6 months etc. or in days, e.g. 7 days, 15 days, 30 days, etc.. The user will enter the details in the form of PREMIUM or DISCOUNT (preceded by the 'minus' sign).
This premium or discount must refer to the one for the currency of the ID against the local currency.

In accordance with the value of the field QUOTATION.PIPS, defined on the CURRENCY table for the ID currency, the system will automatically add/subtract this premium/discount from the Currency table middle rate. Forward rates are used by the Forward revaluation (Rebate method) and also to provide tolerance checks for forward rates on input of a Forward Foreign Exchange transaction.

desc.p: Specifies the Premium/Discount of the currency defined in the ID against local currency for the period stated in the rest period described. The discount must be preceded by the '-' sign.
Example:
If the quotation PIPS for the Deutsche Mark has a value of 4 on the currency table and the Middle rate of the DEM against Local currency is equal to 3.0250:
An input of '200' will automatically generate a Forward rate of 3.0250 + 200 ------ 3.0450
An input of '-150' will automatically generate a Forward rate of 3.0250 - 150 ------ 3.0100
The system will automatically convert the input according to the value defined in the field QUOTATION.PIPS of the currency defined in the ID.
(+/-) Standard exchange rate format.
Indicates whether this rate was input or derived from other rates input.
System generated.
Indicates the period to which a rate applies. The period can be defined for days before spot date or after spot date based on the parameterization of REVALUATION.PARAMETER.
By default, accepts only the period after spot. The period before spot i.e. ON and TOM can be defined only when the field REVAL.WITHIN.SP of REVALUATION.PARAMETER is set to "YES".

The period for days before spot date is prefixed with a negative sign representing ON(-2D) and TOM (-1D) and can be defined only in Days (D). The definition of negative rest period must always start with Today and ends with a day before spot which represents Tomorrow.
For example:

When the spot market is defined as 2 days, the definition of negative rest dates will be -2D for Today and -1D for Tom. Using the Premium/discount defined for -2D and -1D along with Spot rate, system calculates Today's Rate and Tomorrow's Rate. For deriving Today's Rate the Premium/Discount defined for both -2D and -1D will be summated and added/subtracted from the Spot rate. For Tomorrow's Rate, the system will consider -1D.
No interpolation is done while deriving today or Tom rates.

desc.p: A = M for months; D for days; R for rest.
For example, a 12 month rest period would be written as 12M. R must be the last rest period entered.
Specifies the date of the rest period which is calculated by the system according to the value defined in REST.PERIOD.

To calculate the date of the rest period for negative rest period, system will subtract the value defined in REST.PERIOD from the spot date and arrive at the respective working days that fall between Today and Spot date.

To calculate the date of the rest period for positive rest period, system will add to the SPOT date the value defined in the field REST.PERIOD. It is important to note that if the Rest period is defined in months and the date which is calculated happens to be a non-working day, the system will automatically move forward to the next working day after this calculated date. If, however, this next working day falls in the next month, the system will instead move BACKWARD to the previous working day.

This date calculation is generally based on holiday setups of local country and currency country. However if we need the system to calculate the date with some other country holiday setup instead of local country then it can be done through ST.RATE.PARAMETER table.
